item.title: Alpha-beta Pruning
item.description: Search algorithm that decreases the number of gate states to evaluate in [[Minimax Algorithm|Minimax Algorithm]] in the game tree. Stopping condition: It does not evaluate further when it realizes that there is already an existing better alternative.

item.title: Artificial Intelligence Concept Map
item.description: What is AI? From the name, it seems that the aim of artificial intelligence is to create artificially “intelligent” machines. This is a rather loose definition as witnessed by [[Braitenberg vehicles|Braitenberg vehicles]] experiment.

item.title: Assumptions of Linear Regression
item.description: Anscombe’s Quartet - A group of four data sets with nearly identical descriptive statistics, yet different distributions and graphs. These are prime examples of why it’s important to be selective on when to use linear regression!

item.title: Braitenberg vehicles
item.description: Source: Braitenberg Vehicle Wiki This was a thought experiment by Valentino Braitenberg. In the simplest form of this experiment, a Braitenberg vehicle is a machine with a light sensor and a motor.

item.description: [[Programming Paradigm]] [[Data Structures and Algorithm]]

item.title: Data Structures and Algorithm
item.description: Course Textbook: Introduction to Algorithms, 3rd Edition (CLRS) [[Elementary Graph Algorithms.]]

item.title: Elementary Graph Algorithms.
item.description: A graph $G = (V, E)$ is composed of $V$, a set of vertices and $E \in V \times V$

item.title: Ethics in AI
item.description: Filter Bubbles The goal of content recommendation systems, especially those used in social media/newsfeeds, is to provide personalized searches. The unintended effect can be an intellectual isolation - you keep being offered curated results, but you find yourself in a bubble of only your own ideas.

item.title: First-Order Logic
item.description: Gödel’s Theorems i.e. [[../Math/Gödel’s Completeness Theorem|Gödel’s Completeness Theorem]] and [[../Math/Gödel’s Incompleteness Theorem|Gödel’s Incompleteness Theorem|]] were important to AI. From the completeness theorem, automatic theorem provers were created - In the 1950s, the Logic Theorist was made to show computers could process numbers and symbols.

item.title: Function Composition in JavaScript
item.description: JavaScript is a multi-paradigm programming language - it has supports for several [[Programming Paradigm]], including [[Functional Programming]]. Function Piping vs. Composition

item.title: Functional Programming
item.description: What is Functional Programming? A [[Programming Paradigm]]. The main focus is on “what are we trying to solve”, rather than “how are we trying to solve” - It’s a declarative type of programming

item.title: Generating Job Resources based on LinkedIn Job Descriptions
Gesture Recognition with AI to improve Human-Computer Interactions
item.description: Overall Idea Desktop application that can detect hand gestures/ facial expressions and use them as keybinds, allowing them to function as shortcuts or commands.

item.title: Gödel's Completeness Theorem
item.description: For any collection of first-order statements, every semantic implication of those statements is syntactically provable within first-order logic. Simply put,

item.title: Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem
item.description: Source: Numberphile on Gödel’s Incompleteness Theorem The simple idea: There might be a conjecture that’s true, but there is no way to prove it.

item.title: Higher-Order Functions
item.description: A higher-order function is a function which takes a function as a parameter or which returns the function or both. In JavaScript, an example of this is setTimeout() where one of the parameters is a function we run after some time is passed.

item.title: Image Feature Vector
item.description: A way to abstract information i.e. image, so that it’s numerically quantifiable. Simply put, a list of numbers that represents an image.

item.title: Minimax Algorithm
item.description: Decision-theory concept. For simplicity, let’s consider it in the context of a two-player zero sum game like tic-tac-toe. Let there be two players, X and O (their names represent the symbols they need to win on the board).

item.title: Multiple Linear Regression
item.description: Statistical technique that uses two or more independent variables to predict the outcome of a dependent variable determine the relative contribution of each independent variable in total variance Equation of Multiple Linear Regression: $y = b_0 + b_1X_1 + b_2X_2 + + b_3X_3 + … + b_nX_n$

item.title: Programming Paradigm
item.description: Definition: Methods or set of rules to structure code and solve a problem The common types of paradigm: Procedural Programming Logical Programming [[Areas/Computer Science/Functional Programming]] Object-oriented Programming

item.title: Translating Manga or Comic Panels
item.description: This document serves as a place to outline core logic, track progress and record relevant information. Lastly, I need to setup a basic UI for the user to interact with.
